repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body: This test is for unprintable characters. When ZWJ is no longer unprintable some other unprintable character between 0x1000 and 0xFFFF should be used.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3905,7 +3905,7 @@ func Test_normal_gj_on_extra_wide_char()
   put =text
   call cursor(2,1)
   norm! gj
-  call assert_equal([0,2,25,0], getpos('.'))
+  call assert_equal([0,2,29,0], getpos('.'))

comment_data.body: "extra wide" refers to the unprintable char taking 6 cells, which is more than most chars. "unprintable" alone doesn't necessarily have that meaning.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3897,9 +3897,9 @@ func Test_normal_count_after_operator()
   bw!
 endfunc
 
-func Test_normal_gj_on_extra_wide_char()
+func Test_normal_gj_on_unprintable_char()

comment_data.body:
"extra wide" absolutely does not imply that something is at least 6 cells wide. 
"unprintable" refers to a documented, pre-existing thing which is the subject of this test.

if the exact width of 6 is important I will add a comment.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3897,9 +3897,9 @@ func Test_normal_count_after_operator()
   bw!
 endfunc
 
-func Test_normal_gj_on_extra_wide_char()
+func Test_normal_gj_on_unprintable_char()

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
start a new cluster. In addition, 'arabicshape' enables the combining of some
arabic letters when they are shaped to be displayed together in a single cell.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -646,6 +646,12 @@ widespread as file format.
 A composing or combining character is used to change the meaning of the
 character before it.  The combining characters are drawn on top of the
 preceding character.
+
+Nvim largely follows the definition of extended grapheme clusters in UAX#29
+in the unicode standard, with some modifications. An ascii char will always
+start a new cluster. In addition 'arabicshape' enables the combining of some
+arabic letters, when they are shaped to be displayed togheter in a single cell.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
	single width. However, such "text emoji" are treated as full-width
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2217,9 +2217,12 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 			global
 	When on all Unicode emoji characters are considered to be full width.
 	This excludes "text emoji" characters, which are normally displayed as
-	single width.  Unfortunately there is no good specification for this
-	and it has been determined on trial-and-error basis.  Use the
-	|setcellwidths()| function to change the behavior.
+	single width. However, Such "text emoji" are treated as full-width

@@ -793,29 +812,45 @@ int mb_cptr2char_adv(const char **pp)
   return c;
 }
 
+static bool utf_iscomposing_first(int c)
+{
+  return c >= 128 && !utf8proc_grapheme_break(' ', c);
+}
+
 /// Check if the character pointed to by "p2" is a composing character when it
-/// comes after "p1".  For Arabic sometimes "ab" is replaced with "c", which
-/// behaves like a composing character.
-bool utf_composinglike(const char *p1, const char *p2)
+/// comes after "p1".
+///
+/// We use the definition in UAX#29 as implemented by utf8proc with some
+/// exceptions:
+///
+/// - ASCII chars always begin a new cluster. This is a long assumed invariant
+///   in the code base and very useful for performance (we can exit early for ASCII
+///   all over the place, branch predictor go brrr in ascii-only text).
+///   as of unicode 15.1 this will only break BOUNDCLASS_PREPEND followed by ascii,

@@ -793,29 +812,45 @@ int mb_cptr2char_adv(const char **pp)
   return c;
 }
 
+static bool utf_iscomposing_first(int c)
+{
+  return c >= 128 && !utf8proc_grapheme_break(' ', c);
+}
+
 /// Check if the character pointed to by "p2" is a composing character when it
-/// comes after "p1".  For Arabic sometimes "ab" is replaced with "c", which
-/// behaves like a composing character.
-bool utf_composinglike(const char *p1, const char *p2)
+/// comes after "p1".
+///
+/// We use the definition in UAX#29 as implemented by utf8proc with some
+/// exceptions:
+///
+/// - ASCII chars always begin a new cluster. This is a long assumed invariant
+///   in the code base and very useful for performance (we can exit early for ASCII
+///   all over the place, branch predictor go brrr in ascii-only text).
+///   as of unicode 15.1 this will only break BOUNDCLASS_PREPEND followed by ascii,
+///   which should be exceedingly rare (these PREPEND chars are expected to be
+///   followed by multibyte chars within the same script family)
+///
+/// - When 'arabicshape' is active, some pairs of arabic leters "ab" is replaced with

title: support emojis with ZWJ and variant selectors
